The Kenya National Examinations Council
Diploma in Early Childhood Development and Education
December 2008

Instructions to Candidates:

This paper consists of SIX questions. Answer any FIVE questions in the answer booklet provided. Each question carries a total of 20 marks.

Question 1

(a) State four effects of the recommendations of the Gachathi Commission on the Development of Early Childhood Development and Education in Kenya.

Sample Answer:

  • Increased funding for ECDE programs.
  • Expansion of ECDE centers across the country.
  • Improved teacher training and certification.
  • Integration of ECDE into the national education system.

Question 2

(b) Explain nine roles of the community in the implementation of Early Childhood Development and Education programme, according to the Early Childhood Development and Education policy framework.

Sample Answer:

  1. Providing a conducive learning environment.
  2. Participating in the management of ECDE centers.
  3. Supporting the construction and maintenance of facilities.
  4. Encouraging parental involvement in children's education.
  5. Contributing to the development of local curricula.
  6. Providing cultural and traditional knowledge.
  7. Ensuring child protection and welfare.
  8. Organizing community events that promote education.
  9. Monitoring and evaluating the ECDE program's effectiveness.

Question 3

(c) State three ways in which each of the following emerging issues affect child growth and development: (i) urbanization; (ii) changing family structure.

Sample Answer:

(i) Urbanization:

  • Increased exposure to diverse cultures and technologies.
  • Potential for higher stress due to crowded living conditions.
  • Access to better educational resources and healthcare.

(ii) Changing family structure:

  • Impact of single-parent households on child emotional development.
  • Increased reliance on extended family or caregivers.
  • Effects of blended families on social relationships.

Question 4

(a) Describe the four stages of Ralph Tyler’s theory of the curriculum development process.

Sample Answer:

  1. Determining educational objectives.
  2. Selecting learning experiences.
  3. Organizing learning experiences.
  4. Evaluating the curriculum's effectiveness.

Question 5

(c) Explain five ways you would use to develop social equality when handling children in the Early Childhood Development and Education curriculum.

Sample Answer:

  • Ensuring inclusive educational activities that accommodate all children.
  • Providing equal access to resources and learning materials.
  • Encouraging interactions among children from diverse backgrounds.
  • Implementing anti-bias education to promote equality.
  • Training teachers to recognize and address social inequalities.

Question 6

(b) Give five reasons why the stage of evaluation in curriculum development is important.

Sample Answer:

  1. To assess whether educational objectives are being met.
  2. To identify areas that need improvement.
  3. To ensure the curriculum remains relevant and effective.
  4. To provide feedback for curriculum revision.
  5. To measure student learning outcomes and progress.

Instructions to Candidates:

This paper consists of SIX questions. Answer any FIVE questions in the answer booklet provided. Each question carries a total of 20 marks.

Question 1

(a) Describe four components of philosophy. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Metaphysics: The study of reality and existence.
  • Epistemology: The study of knowledge and how it is acquired.
  • Ethics: The study of moral values and principles.
  • Aesthetics: The study of beauty and art.

(b) Identify four ways in which a teacher would use the concept of philosophy in Early Childhood Development and Education (ECDE). (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • To guide curriculum development and implementation.
  • To inform teaching methods and strategies.
  • To create a conducive learning environment.
  • To promote critical thinking and problem-solving skills in children.

(c) Explain four methods through which values were imparted to young children in Traditional African Society. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Storytelling: Elders used stories to teach moral lessons and cultural values.
  • Modeling Behavior: Children learned by observing and imitating adults.
  • Community Involvement: Children participated in communal activities to learn social values.
  • Ceremonial Practices: Rituals and ceremonies reinforced cultural and spiritual values.

Question 2

(a) Outline five roles played by missionaries in the establishment of ECDE in Kenya. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Establishing the first formal schools for young children.
  2. Introducing Western education systems and curricula.
  3. Providing resources such as books and teaching materials.
  4. Training local teachers to work in ECDE centers.
  5. Promoting the importance of early childhood education in communities.

(b) Give eight negative effects of Free Primary Education (FPE) on ECDE in Kenya. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Reduced funding for ECDE programs as resources were diverted to FPE.
  • Overcrowding in primary schools, leading to neglect of ECDE.
  • Decline in the quality of ECDE due to lack of trained teachers.
  • Increased dropout rates in ECDE as parents focused on free primary education.
  • Lack of infrastructure development for ECDE centers.
  • Reduced parental involvement in ECDE programs.
  • Shift in government priorities away from ECDE.
  • Increased pressure on ECDE teachers to meet primary school standards.

(c) Examine seven benefits of government policies on ECDE in Kenya. (7 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Increased access to ECDE programs for children across the country.
  • Standardization of the ECDE curriculum to ensure quality education.
  • Provision of funding and resources for ECDE centers.
  • Training and professional development opportunities for ECDE teachers.
  • Improved infrastructure and facilities for ECDE centers.
  • Enhanced community involvement and support for ECDE programs.
  • Promotion of inclusive education for children with special needs.

Question 3

(a) Highlight five ways in which a pre-school teacher would use the philosophy of John Pestalozzi in the classroom situation. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Emphasizing hands-on learning and experiential activities.
  • Focusing on the holistic development of the child (physical, emotional, and intellectual).
  • Using child-centered teaching methods to cater to individual needs.
  • Encouraging active participation and interaction among children.
  • Integrating moral and ethical education into the curriculum.

(b) (i) Identify five ways of naming children in Traditional African Society. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Based on the circumstances of birth (e.g., time, season, or events).
  • Named after ancestors or relatives to honor them.
  • Named after significant cultural or spiritual beliefs.
  • Named based on the child's physical characteristics or behavior.
  • Named after important community leaders or heroes.

(ii) Explain five reasons for naming children in Traditional African Society. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • To preserve family and cultural heritage.
  • To honor ancestors and maintain a connection with the past.
  • To reflect the circumstances or events surrounding the child's birth.
  • To instill a sense of identity and belonging in the child.
  • To convey hopes and aspirations for the child's future.

Question 4

(a) Differentiate between collage and mosaic as used in creative activities. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Collage: A technique where various materials (e.g., paper, fabric, photographs) are glued onto a surface to create a composition.
  • Mosaic: A technique where small pieces of materials (e.g., tiles, glass, stones) are arranged to form a pattern or image.

(b) Outline six roles played by the National Centre for Early Childhood Education (NACECE) in ECDE in Kenya. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Developing and revising the ECDE curriculum.
  • Training and capacity building for ECDE teachers.
  • Conducting research on ECDE practices and policies.
  • Providing technical support and guidance to ECDE centers.
  • Promoting community awareness and involvement in ECDE.
  • Monitoring and evaluating the implementation of ECDE programs.

(c) Explain six challenges that affect the implementation of the ECDE curriculum in Kenya. (12 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Inadequate funding and resources for ECDE programs.
  • Lack of trained and qualified ECDE teachers.
  • Poor infrastructure and facilities in ECDE centers.
  • Low parental and community involvement in ECDE activities.
  • Inconsistent implementation of ECDE policies across regions.
  • High teacher-to-child ratios, leading to overcrowded classrooms.

Question 5

(a) Define the term curriculum. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

A curriculum refers to the planned and structured set of learning experiences and content designed to achieve specific educational goals and objectives.

(b) Discuss six steps that take place during the process of development of ECDE curriculum support materials by the Kenya Institute of Education (KIE). (12 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Conducting a needs assessment to identify gaps in the current curriculum.
  2. Setting clear objectives and goals for the new curriculum materials.
  3. Designing and drafting the curriculum content and materials.
  4. Reviewing and revising the draft materials based on feedback.
  5. Piloting the materials in selected ECDE centers to test their effectiveness.
  6. Finalizing and distributing the materials to all ECDE centers.

(c) Give five reasons for the involvement of Directorate of Quality Assurance and Standards in the Ministry of Education in ECDE curriculum development in Kenya. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • To ensure the curriculum meets national education standards.
  • To monitor and evaluate the implementation of the curriculum.
  • To provide technical support and guidance to curriculum developers.
  • To ensure the curriculum is relevant and responsive to the needs of learners.
  • To promote quality assurance and continuous improvement in ECDE programs.

Question 6

(a) Give five ways in which the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) is involved in the development of curriculum in ECDE in Kenya. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Recruiting and training qualified ECDE teachers.
  • Providing professional development opportunities for ECDE teachers.
  • Ensuring teachers adhere to the national curriculum guidelines.
  • Monitoring and evaluating the performance of ECDE teachers.
  • Collaborating with other stakeholders to improve ECDE curriculum implementation.

(b) Highlight five considerations a teacher would make when planning for teaching-learning activities in the development of the ECDE curriculum. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • The age and developmental level of the children.
  • The learning objectives and outcomes of the curriculum.
  • The availability of teaching resources and materials.
  • The cultural and social background of the children.
  • The need for inclusive and differentiated instruction.

(c) Assess five challenges of rural-urban migration that may affect ECDE in Kenya. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Overcrowding in urban ECDE centers due to increased population.
  • Strain on resources and infrastructure in urban areas.
  • Decline in the quality of ECDE in rural areas due to reduced population.
  • Increased demand for ECDE services in urban areas, leading to higher costs.
  • Disruption of family structures, affecting children's emotional and social development.

Question 1

(a) Explain the term, ‘sociology’. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

Sociology is the study of human social relationships, institutions, and societies. It examines how individuals interact within social structures and how these structures influence behavior.

(b) Explain five rights of a parent as outlined in the Children’s Act 2001. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Right to care and protection of the child.
  2. Right to provide guidance and discipline.
  3. Right to make decisions regarding the child's education.
  4. Right to access information about the child's welfare.
  5. Right to participate in the child's upbringing and development.

(c) Suggest four measures that an ECDE centre can take to reduce incidences of child abuse. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Implementing strict child protection policies.
  2. Training staff on recognizing and reporting abuse.
  3. Creating a safe and supportive environment for children.
  4. Encouraging open communication with parents and guardians.

Question 2

(a) Outline four challenges facing ECDE after the introduction of Free Primary Education (F.P.E.). (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Increased enrollment leading to overcrowding.
  2. Inadequate funding for ECDE programs.
  3. Shortage of trained ECDE teachers.
  4. Lack of adequate infrastructure and resources.

(b) Explain five similarities between Maria Montessori’s and Froebel’s Philosophies of Early Childhood learning. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Both emphasize the importance of play in learning.
  2. Both advocate for child-centered education.
  3. Both stress the importance of the environment in learning.
  4. Both believe in the natural development of the child.
  5. Both promote hands-on learning experiences.

(c) Explain three measures that an ECDE centre in Kenya can take to mitigate hunger. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Providing school feeding programs.
  2. Partnering with NGOs for food donations.
  3. Educating parents on nutrition and food security.

Question 3

(a) Describe four ways through which the African traditional society imparted skills in young children. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Through storytelling and oral traditions.
  2. By involving children in daily chores and activities.
  3. Through apprenticeship and mentorship.
  4. By participating in cultural ceremonies and rituals.

(b) Highlight three principles advocated by Jean Jacques Rousseau that are in practice today in ECDE centres in Kenya. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Child-centered learning.
  2. Learning through experience and exploration.
  3. Respect for the natural development of the child.

(c) Discuss three similarities between the provision of ECDE in Kenya and Ghana. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Both countries emphasize the importance of early childhood education.
  2. Both face challenges related to funding and resources.
  3. Both have government policies supporting ECDE programs.

Question 4

(a) Explain the term, ‘hidden curriculum.’ (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

The hidden curriculum refers to the unwritten, unofficial, and often unintended lessons, values, and perspectives that students learn in school, such as social norms and cultural expectations.

(b) Highlight four goals of education in Kenya and give relevant examples of how the ECDE curriculum is helping attain these goals. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Promoting national unity: ECDE curriculum includes activities that encourage cooperation and understanding among children from different backgrounds.
  2. Fostering individual development: The curriculum focuses on holistic development, including cognitive, emotional, and social skills.
  3. Promoting social equality: ECDE programs aim to provide equal opportunities for all children, regardless of their socio-economic status.
  4. Preparing children for future education: The curriculum lays a strong foundation for primary education by developing basic literacy and numeracy skills.

(c) Explain five instruments that the Kenya Institute of Education (K.I.E.) may use to evaluate the ECDE curriculum. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Surveys and questionnaires.
  2. Classroom observations.
  3. Interviews with teachers and parents.
  4. Standardized tests.
  5. Focus group discussions.

Question 5

(a) List the seven steps of curriculum development as indicated in Gilbert P. Olnoch’s theory. (7 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Needs assessment.
  2. Setting objectives.
  3. Content selection.
  4. Organization of content.
  5. Selection of learning experiences.
  6. Organization of learning experiences.
  7. Evaluation.

(b) Explain four categories of physical and outdoor activities in which learners may be involved. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Sports and games: Activities like football, athletics, and relay races.
  2. Nature exploration: Activities like gardening, nature walks, and bird watching.
  3. Creative play: Activities like building sandcastles, playing with water, and role-playing.
  4. Adventure activities: Activities like obstacle courses, camping, and hiking.

(c) State five measures that can be taken to reduce negative effect of commercializing ECDE teacher training in Kenya. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Regulating private training institutions.
  2. Providing government subsidies for teacher training.
  3. Enhancing quality assurance mechanisms.
  4. Encouraging public-private partnerships.
  5. Promoting continuous professional development for teachers.

Question 6

(a) Explain four principles that should govern ECDE curriculum development according to Jerome Bruner. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Spiral organization: Revisiting key concepts at increasing levels of complexity.
  2. Readiness: Ensuring that the curriculum is appropriate for the child's developmental stage.
  3. Intuitive thinking: Encouraging children to explore and discover knowledge on their own.
  4. Motivation: Creating a curriculum that engages and motivates children to learn.

(b) State four ways in which an ECDE centre can promote health care needs of the learners. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Providing regular health check-ups.
  2. Ensuring a clean and safe environment.
  3. Educating children on hygiene practices.
  4. Offering nutritious meals and snacks.

(c) Discuss the role of the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) in the development and implementation of curriculum in Kenya. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

The Teachers Service Commission (TSC) plays a crucial role in curriculum development and implementation by recruiting, training, and deploying qualified teachers. It also ensures that teachers are continuously trained on new curriculum changes and provides guidelines for effective curriculum delivery. Additionally, TSC monitors and evaluates the performance of teachers to ensure that the curriculum is effectively implemented in schools.

  • They ensure the continuation of the family lineage.
  • Children offer social security to parents in old age.
  • They enhance the social status of parents within the community.
  • Children contribute to the family's economic well-being through their future earnings.
  • They bring joy and emotional fulfillment to parents.

(b) Examine six negative effects of HIV and AIDS on the ECDE teacher. (6 marks)

  • Increased absenteeism due to illness.
  • Reduced productivity and performance.
  • Emotional and psychological stress.
  • Financial strain due to medical expenses.
  • Stigmatization and discrimination from colleagues and the community.
  • Increased workload for healthy teachers due to staff shortages.

(c) Explain four benefits of a sociology lesson to an ECDE teacher. (8 marks)

  • Enhances understanding of social dynamics and cultural diversity.
  • Improves ability to address social issues affecting children.
  • Promotes effective communication with parents and the community.
  • Encourages the development of inclusive teaching practices.

Question 2

(a) Identify four objectives of ECDE in Uganda. (4 marks)

  • To promote holistic development of children.
  • To prepare children for primary education.
  • To enhance children's social and emotional skills.
  • To provide a foundation for lifelong learning.

(b) Discuss four contributions of Maria Montessori in the development of ECDE curriculum. (8 marks)

  • Emphasized child-centered learning.
  • Introduced the use of sensory-based learning materials.
  • Advocated for individualized learning plans.
  • Promoted the importance of a prepared learning environment.

(c) Suggest four measures the Government of Kenya should put in place to ensure provision of quality education in early childhood in Arid and Semi-arid Lands. (8 marks)

  • Increase funding for ECDE programs in these regions.
  • Provide training and support for ECDE teachers.
  • Improve infrastructure and learning materials.
  • Implement community awareness programs on the importance of early childhood education.

Question 3

(a) Identify four forms of child abuse that can take place in an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

  • Physical abuse.
  • Emotional abuse.
  • Sexual abuse.
  • Neglect.

(b) Describe four characteristics of Traditional African Education. (8 marks)

  • It was community-oriented and focused on communal values.
  • It emphasized practical skills and vocational training.
  • It was oral-based, with knowledge passed down through storytelling.
  • It included initiation rites as a form of transition to adulthood.

(c) Explain four ways in which an ECDE teacher can use language activities to promote hard work in the learners. (8 marks)

  • Encourage storytelling that highlights the value of hard work.
  • Use songs and rhymes that promote diligence and perseverance.
  • Incorporate role-playing activities that model hard work.
  • Provide positive reinforcement and praise for effort and achievement.

Question 4

(a) Differentiate between curriculum and syllabus. (4 marks)

  • Curriculum refers to the overall content, structure, and objectives of an educational program.
  • Syllabus is a detailed outline of topics to be covered in a specific course or subject.

(b) Describe three elements of school curriculum according to Gilbert P. Oltoch. (6 marks)

  • Objectives: The goals and outcomes the curriculum aims to achieve.
  • Content: The subject matter and topics included in the curriculum.
  • Evaluation: The methods used to assess student learning and curriculum effectiveness.

(c) Explain five functions of NACECE in curriculum development. (10 marks)

  • Developing and reviewing ECDE curriculum.
  • Providing training and support for ECDE teachers.
  • Conducting research on early childhood education.
  • Monitoring and evaluating the implementation of ECDE programs.
  • Advising the government on ECDE policies and practices.

Question 5

(a) Identify four categories of children who may not easily access regular ECDE services. (4 marks)

  • Children with disabilities.
  • Children from marginalized communities.
  • Orphans and vulnerable children.
  • Children in remote or conflict-affected areas.

(b) Highlight three negative effects of liberalization of ECDE Teacher training in the country. (6 marks)

  • Decline in the quality of teacher training programs.
  • Increased commercialization of teacher training.
  • Lack of standardization and regulation in training institutions.

(c) Explain five achievements of sessional paper No.1 of 2005 in the ECDE sector. (10 marks)

  • Increased enrollment in ECDE programs.
  • Improved infrastructure and learning materials.
  • Enhanced teacher training and professional development.
  • Strengthened policy framework for early childhood education.
  • Increased community involvement in ECDE programs.

(a) Explain the roles of the following in curriculum development process. (i) course panel (3 marks) (ii) academic board (3 marks)

  • Course Panel: Responsible for designing and reviewing the curriculum, ensuring it meets educational standards and objectives.
  • Academic Board: Oversees the overall academic policies and approves the curriculum developed by the course panel.

(b) Outline six roles of the Directorate of Quality Assurance and Standards in the implementation of ECDE curriculum in Kenya. (6 marks)

  • Monitoring and evaluating the implementation of the curriculum.
  • Providing guidelines and standards for curriculum delivery.
  • Conducting inspections and assessments of ECDE centers.
  • Offering training and support to ECDE teachers.
  • Ensuring compliance with national education policies.
  • Collecting and analyzing data on curriculum effectiveness.

(c) Describe four merits of evaluation in ECDE curriculum. (8 marks)

  • Identifies strengths and weaknesses in the curriculum.
  • Provides feedback for continuous improvement.
  • Ensures accountability and quality assurance.
  • Supports decision-making for curriculum adjustments.

Question 1

(a) Outline two positive effects of the Gachathi Report (1976) to ECDE. (4 marks)

1. The Gachathi Report led to the establishment of more Early Childhood Development and Education (ECDE) centers, increasing access to early education.

2. It emphasized the importance of teacher training, leading to improved quality of education in ECDE centers.

(b) Explain three factors of urbanization that have impacted positively on Early Childhood Development and Education. (6 marks)

1. Urbanization has led to better infrastructure, such as schools and healthcare facilities, which support ECDE.

2. Increased access to information and communication technologies (ICT) in urban areas has enhanced learning opportunities for young children.

3. Urban areas often have more diverse populations, which can enrich the cultural experiences of children in ECDE centers.

(c) “Education in Kenya should foster nationalism, patriotism and promote national unity”. State five learning activities through which the above national goal of education can be implemented in ECDE. (10 marks)

1. Celebrating national holidays and teaching children about their significance.

2. Singing the national anthem and other patriotic songs.

3. Organizing cultural days where children learn about different ethnic groups in Kenya.

4. Teaching children about national heroes and their contributions to the country.

5. Encouraging community service projects that promote unity and cooperation.

Question 2

(a) State two ways in which home-based care centres have enhanced early childhood learning. (4 marks)

1. Home-based care centers provide a familiar and comfortable environment for young children, which can enhance their learning experience.

2. They offer personalized attention to children, allowing for tailored learning experiences that meet individual needs.

(b) Highlight three positive skills acquired by children from watching television. (6 marks)

1. Language and communication skills through educational programs and storytelling.

2. Cognitive skills such as problem-solving and critical thinking from interactive shows.

3. Social skills by observing and learning from characters' interactions and behaviors.

(c) Identify five protective rights as indicated in the Children’s Act, 2001. (10 marks)

1. The right to protection from abuse, neglect, and exploitation.

2. The right to education and access to educational materials.

3. The right to healthcare and access to medical services.

4. The right to protection from harmful cultural practices.

5. The right to be protected from child labor and hazardous work.

Question 3

(a) Highlight two challenges experienced by ECDE teachers working with pastoral communities. (4 marks)

1. Limited access to educational resources and materials due to the remote locations of pastoral communities.

2. High mobility of pastoral families, which can lead to inconsistent attendance of children in ECDE centers.

(b) Outline four characteristics of ECDE centres established by the missionaries at pre-independence. (8 marks)

1. They were often attached to churches and had a strong religious influence on the curriculum.

2. The centers focused on basic literacy and numeracy skills.

3. They provided education primarily to the children of converts and local elites.

4. The centers were often underfunded and relied on donations and support from missionary organizations.

(c) “The learners were busy and enjoying the free-choice activities; The teacher sung a familiar song for them to stop and change over”. Highlight four advantages of involving learners in the clearing up activity. (8 marks)

1. It teaches children responsibility and the importance of taking care of their environment.

2. It helps develop fine motor skills as children handle and organize materials.

3. It encourages teamwork and cooperation among children.

4. It provides a smooth transition between activities, reducing chaos and confusion.

Question 4

(a) State the meaning of the term education. (2 marks)

Education is the process of facilitating learning, acquiring knowledge, skills, values, beliefs, and habits through various methods such as teaching, training, or research.

(b) Explain the sources of curriculum objectives according to Ralph Tyler. (6 marks)

1. Studies of the learners themselves: Understanding the needs, interests, and abilities of the students.

2. Studies of contemporary life: Identifying the skills and knowledge needed in modern society.

3. Suggestions from subject matter specialists: Input from experts in various fields to determine essential content.

(c) Using an illustration, explain Hilda Taba’s model of curriculum development. (12 marks)

Hilda Taba’s model of curriculum development is a grassroots approach that involves teachers in the process. The model consists of the following steps:

  1. Diagnosis of needs: Identifying the needs of the learners and the community.
  2. Formulation of objectives: Defining clear and specific learning objectives based on the diagnosed needs.
  3. Selection of content: Choosing appropriate content that aligns with the objectives.
  4. Organization of content: Structuring the content in a logical and meaningful sequence.
  5. Selection of learning experiences: Designing activities and experiences that facilitate learning.
  6. Organization of learning experiences: Arranging the learning experiences in a coherent manner.
  7. Evaluation: Assessing the effectiveness of the curriculum and making necessary adjustments.

This model emphasizes the importance of teacher involvement and a bottom-up approach to curriculum development.

Question 5

(a) State two roles of District Centres for Early Childhood Education in the implementation of Early Childhood Development and Education curriculum. (2 marks)

1. Providing training and professional development for ECDE teachers.

2. Monitoring and evaluating the implementation of the ECDE curriculum in local centers.

(b) Describe four ways of imparting social skills to ECDE learners. (8 marks)

1. Encouraging group activities and cooperative play to foster teamwork and communication.

2. Teaching children to share and take turns through structured games and activities.

3. Modeling positive social behaviors and interactions for children to emulate.

4. Using role-playing and storytelling to teach empathy and understanding of others' feelings.

(c) Explain five activities each from the sub theme: Sun, that a preschool teacher can organise for five-year old’s, in Creative arts and Science lessons. (10 marks)

Creative Arts:

  1. Drawing and painting pictures of the sun.
  2. Creating sun-shaped crafts using paper plates and yellow paint.
  3. Singing songs about the sun and its importance.
  4. Making sun catchers using colored tissue paper and clear contact paper.
  5. Role-playing as the sun and other celestial bodies in a simple play.

Science:

  1. Observing and discussing the effects of sunlight on plants.
  2. Conducting simple experiments to show how the sun affects temperature.
  3. Creating a sundial to understand how the sun's position changes throughout the day.
  4. Discussing the importance of the sun for life on Earth.
  5. Exploring the concept of day and night using a globe and a flashlight to represent the sun.

Question 6

(a) Highlight two measures an ECDE teacher may use to discourage early marriages. (4 marks)

1. Educating children and their parents about the negative consequences of early marriage, such as health risks and limited educational opportunities.

2. Promoting gender equality and empowering girls through education and awareness programs.

(b) Outline three measures that can be undertaken to improve health, safety and nutrition within ECDE centres. (6 marks)

1. Implementing regular health check-ups and vaccinations for children.

2. Ensuring that the ECDE centers have safe and clean environments, including proper sanitation and hygiene practices.

3. Providing balanced and nutritious meals to children, and educating parents about the importance of good nutrition.

(c) (i) State two challenges the government may face in implementing ICT in ECDE. (4 marks)

1. Limited infrastructure and access to technology in rural areas.

2. Lack of trained teachers who can effectively integrate ICT into the curriculum.

(ii) Identify three ways in which ICT can enhance the learning environment in Early Childhood Development Education Centres. (6 marks)

1. Providing interactive and engaging learning materials, such as educational games and videos.

2. Facilitating communication and collaboration between teachers, parents, and students through digital platforms.

3. Offering access to a wide range of online resources and information that can supplement traditional teaching methods.

Diploma in Early Childhood Development and Education
December 2016

Instructions to Candidates:

Answer any FIVE questions. Use clear and concise language.

Question 1

(a) Distinguish between the philosophies of Johann H. Pestalozzi and Friedrich W. Froebel in Early Childhood Development and Education. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Johann H. Pestalozzi emphasized the importance of sensory learning and believed that education should be based on the natural development of the child.
  • Friedrich W. Froebel, on the other hand, is known for developing the concept of kindergarten and believed in the importance of play and self-activity in early childhood education.

(b) Explain the following provisions as outlined in the Children’s Act, 2001:

(i) Right to parental care; (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • The Children’s Act, 2001, guarantees every child the right to parental care, which includes the right to live with and be cared for by their parents or guardians.

(ii) Protection from child labour and armed conflict. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • The Act protects children from engaging in child labour and from being recruited or used in armed conflict, ensuring their safety and well-being.

(c) Discuss five reasons that make philosophy relevant to ECDE teachers. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Philosophy helps teachers understand the purpose and goals of education.
  2. It provides a framework for making decisions about curriculum and teaching methods.
  3. Philosophy encourages critical thinking and reflection on teaching practices.
  4. It helps teachers develop a personal teaching philosophy that guides their interactions with children.
  5. Philosophy promotes a deeper understanding of child development and learning theories.

Question 2

(a) State two differences between The African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child, 1990 and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, 1989. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • The African Charter specifically addresses issues relevant to African children, such as cultural practices and armed conflicts, while the UN Convention has a more global perspective.
  • The African Charter emphasizes the role of the community in child upbringing, whereas the UN Convention focuses more on the role of the state and parents.

(b) Explain four positive ways in which children were perceived in African Traditional Societies. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Children were seen as a blessing and a continuation of the family lineage.
  2. They were valued for their potential to contribute to the community’s future.
  3. Children were often involved in communal activities, fostering a sense of belonging.
  4. They were respected and cared for by the entire community, not just their immediate family.

(c) Outline four negative effects of illiterate parents on ECDE learners. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Illiterate parents may struggle to support their children’s learning at home.
  2. They may not understand the importance of early childhood education, leading to low enrollment rates.
  3. Illiterate parents may have limited communication with teachers, affecting the child’s progress.
  4. They may not be able to provide a stimulating learning environment at home.

Question 3

(a) Identify two similarities of ECDE objectives in Kenya and Ghana. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Both countries aim to provide a strong foundation for lifelong learning and development.
  • Both emphasize the importance of holistic development, including physical, emotional, and social growth.

(b) State four achievements of the pre-school education project co-founded by the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology and Bernard Van Leer Foundation. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Increased access to pre-school education for children in underserved areas.
  2. Improved quality of early childhood education through teacher training programs.
  3. Development of culturally relevant teaching materials.
  4. Enhanced community involvement in early childhood education initiatives.

(c) Explain five ways in which ECDE learners may benefit from mobile schools as a measure to increase access to basic education. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Mobile schools can reach remote and marginalized communities, providing access to education for children who would otherwise be excluded.
  2. They offer flexible learning schedules, accommodating the needs of children who may have other responsibilities.
  3. Mobile schools can provide a safe and supportive learning environment, especially in areas affected by conflict or natural disasters.
  4. They can deliver tailored educational programs that meet the specific needs of the community.
  5. Mobile schools can help bridge the gap in education during emergencies, ensuring continuity of learning.

Question 4

(a) Explain the term syllabus. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • A syllabus is a document that outlines the topics, objectives, and content to be covered in a particular course or subject.

(b) State four approaches of sustaining learners attention in an ECDE class. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Use of interactive and engaging teaching methods, such as storytelling and games.
  2. Incorporating visual aids and hands-on activities to make learning more interesting.
  3. Maintaining a positive and supportive classroom environment.
  4. Providing regular breaks and opportunities for physical activity to keep children focused.

(c) Identify five factors considered when including topics of a subject in the syllabus. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Relevance to the learners’ age and developmental stage.
  2. Alignment with the overall educational goals and objectives.
  3. Cultural and social relevance to the learners’ context.
  4. Availability of resources and teaching materials.
  5. Feedback from educators and stakeholders on the importance of the topics.

Question 5

(a) Give two benefits of devolving ECDE services to the county governments. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Devolving ECDE services allows for more localized decision-making, ensuring that programs are tailored to the specific needs of the community.
  • It can lead to more efficient use of resources, as county governments are better positioned to identify and address local challenges.

(b) Describe three challenges the Kindergarten Headmistresses’ Association (KHA) may face in performing its duties. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Limited funding and resources to support their initiatives.
  2. Difficulty in coordinating efforts across different regions and schools.
  3. Resistance to change from some educators and stakeholders.

(c) Explain five functions of Education Standard and Quality Assurance Council in ECDE curriculum development. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Setting and maintaining standards for early childhood education.
  2. Monitoring and evaluating the implementation of the curriculum.
  3. Providing guidance and support to educators on curriculum delivery.
  4. Conducting research to inform curriculum development and improvement.
  5. Ensuring that the curriculum is inclusive and meets the needs of all learners.

Question 6

(a) Identify four ways in which national unity can be nurtured in an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Promoting cultural diversity and inclusion through activities and celebrations.
  2. Teaching children about the importance of unity and cooperation.
  3. Encouraging collaborative projects and group activities.
  4. Providing opportunities for children to interact with peers from different backgrounds.

(b) Name and explain the three levels of presentation that children go through according to Jerome Brunner. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Enactive Level: Children learn through direct manipulation of objects and physical actions.
  2. Iconic Level: Children use images and visual representations to understand concepts.
  3. Symbolic Level: Children use symbols, such as language and numbers, to represent ideas and solve problems.

(c) Describe five contributions of Jean Piaget to Early Childhood Development and Education. (10 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Piaget’s theory of cognitive development provides a framework for understanding how children learn and think.
  2. He emphasized the importance of play in children’s learning and development.
  3. Piaget introduced the concept of stages of development, which helps educators tailor their teaching methods to the child’s developmental level.
  4. He highlighted the role of active learning, where children construct knowledge through exploration and experimentation.
  5. Piaget’s work has influenced the development of child-centered approaches to education.

Instructions to Candidates:

Answer any FIVE questions. Use clear and concise language.

Question 1

(a) (i) State two characteristics of Early Childhood Development and Education. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Focus on holistic development, including physical, emotional, social, and cognitive growth.
  • Emphasis on play-based learning to foster creativity and exploration.

(ii) Outline two practices adopted from Maria Montessori in Early Childhood Development and Education. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Use of self-directed learning activities that allow children to choose their tasks.
  • Incorporation of sensory-based materials to enhance learning through hands-on experiences.

(b) Highlight three differences between the traditional and contemporary concept of the African child. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Traditional views often saw children as communal property, while contemporary views emphasize individual rights and needs.
  2. In traditional societies, children were expected to contribute to household chores early, whereas contemporary views advocate for age-appropriate responsibilities.
  3. Traditional education was informal and community-based, while contemporary education is formal and structured.

(c) Explain four challenges of integrating pre-primary into the primary school system. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Lack of adequate infrastructure to accommodate younger children.
  2. Insufficient training for primary school teachers to handle pre-primary learners.
  3. Differences in curriculum requirements and teaching methodologies.
  4. Potential neglect of the unique developmental needs of pre-primary children in a primary school setting.

Question 2

(a) State four ways in which needs assessment is important in the curriculum development process. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Identifies the specific needs and gaps in the current curriculum.
  2. Helps in setting clear and achievable educational goals.
  3. Ensures that the curriculum is relevant to the learners’ needs and societal demands.
  4. Provides a basis for resource allocation and prioritization.

(b) Describe three contributions of Jean Piaget to ECDE. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Piaget’s theory of cognitive development provides a framework for understanding how children learn and think.
  2. He emphasized the importance of play in children’s learning and development.
  3. Piaget introduced the concept of stages of development, which helps educators tailor their teaching methods to the child’s developmental level.

(c) (i) State two main activities a teacher would use to instil obedience in ECDE learners. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Use of positive reinforcement to reward good behavior.
  • Setting clear and consistent rules and expectations.

(ii) Identify four reasons for considering chronological age of a child before admission to pre-school. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. To ensure the child is developmentally ready for the activities and learning experiences.
  2. To align with the cognitive and social-emotional milestones expected at that age.
  3. To maintain a consistent learning environment for all children in the class.
  4. To comply with legal and regulatory requirements for school admission.

Question 3

(a) Explain the term subject as used in curriculum development. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • A subject refers to a specific area of knowledge or study that is taught as part of the curriculum, such as mathematics, science, or language arts.

(b) (i) State four features of a day care centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Provides care and supervision for children during the day.
  2. Offers structured activities and learning opportunities.
  3. Ensures a safe and nurturing environment for children.
  4. May provide meals and snacks for the children.

(ii) Highlight three possible challenges the county governments may face in managing day care centres. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Limited funding and resources to maintain quality standards.
  2. Difficulty in recruiting and retaining qualified staff.
  3. Ensuring compliance with health and safety regulations.

(c) Describe four activities that can enhance the development of reading skills in preschoolers. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Reading aloud to children to model fluent reading.
  2. Encouraging children to retell stories in their own words.
  3. Using picture books to help children associate words with images.
  4. Providing opportunities for children to practice writing and recognizing letters.

Question 4

(a) Identify four effects of poverty on the development of ECDE infrastructure. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Limited funding for building and maintaining school facilities.
  2. Inadequate supply of learning materials and resources.
  3. Poor sanitation and hygiene conditions in schools.
  4. Overcrowded classrooms due to lack of space and resources.

(b) Describe four economic factors that lead to curriculum change. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Changes in labor market demands requiring new skills and knowledge.
  2. Economic downturns leading to budget cuts and resource constraints.
  3. Globalization and the need for a competitive workforce.
  4. Technological advancements requiring updated curriculum content.

(c) Discuss four negative socio-economic effects of single parenthood on an ECDE learner. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Financial strain leading to limited access to educational resources.
  2. Reduced parental involvement due to work commitments.
  3. Emotional stress affecting the child’s learning and behavior.
  4. Social stigma and isolation from peers.

Question 5

(a) Identify four differences in the functions of DICECE and NACECE. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. DICECE focuses on district-level implementation of ECDE programs, while NACECE oversees national policies and standards.
  2. DICECE provides direct support to local ECDE centers, whereas NACECE conducts research and development.
  3. DICECE is responsible for training and capacity building at the district level, while NACECE sets national training guidelines.
  4. DICECE monitors and evaluates ECDE programs within its district, while NACECE ensures compliance with national standards.

(b) (i) State four roles of the university in ECDE curriculum development. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Conducting research to inform curriculum content and teaching methods.
  2. Providing training and professional development for ECDE educators.
  3. Developing and updating curriculum frameworks and guidelines.
  4. Collaborating with other stakeholders to ensure the curriculum meets societal needs.

(ii) Discuss two effects of breakdown of extended families on a child's upbringing. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Reduced emotional and social support for the child, leading to potential behavioral issues.
  2. Increased financial burden on the nuclear family, affecting the child’s access to resources and opportunities.

(c) Explain four measures an ECDE teacher can adopt to enhance participatory rights of a learner. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Encouraging children to express their opinions and ideas during class discussions.
  2. Providing opportunities for children to make choices in their learning activities.
  3. Creating a classroom environment that respects and values each child’s contributions.
  4. Involving children in decision-making processes, such as setting classroom rules.

Question 6

(a) Highlight three negative effects of African resistance movement to colonial rule on ECDE development in Kenya. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Disruption of traditional education systems, leading to a loss of cultural knowledge.
  2. Destruction of community structures that supported early childhood care and education.
  3. Diverted resources from education to fund resistance efforts, delaying the development of formal ECDE systems.

(b) Explain three measures an ECDE teacher can put in place to curb bullying amongst the learners. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Establishing clear anti-bullying policies and consequences.
  2. Promoting a culture of respect and inclusion through classroom activities.
  3. Providing support and counseling for both victims and perpetrators of bullying.

(c) Outline four practices an ECDE teacher can inculcate in the learners to enhance environmental hygiene. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Teaching children the importance of handwashing and proper hygiene practices.
  2. Encouraging children to keep their classroom and play areas clean.
  3. Organizing regular clean-up activities to instill a sense of responsibility.
  4. Using visual aids and stories to explain the impact of hygiene on health.
